head.title: Hunting Song.11 Published in Columbian Herald and New Daily Advertiser [Charleston, SC] (April 26, 1796).

body.note: Tune--Bright Phoebus.22 The first published version of this air was in 1790. WorldCat attributes it to James Hook (1746-1827), for half a century the keyboard artist for the Vauxhall Gardens, one of the first performers in England to use the pianoforte for a concerto, and composer of over 2000 songs, including music for over thirty stage works for Drury Lane and Covent Garden theatres (ODNB).

lg.l: When Phoebus33 God of light, or the sun. first tinges the welin with red,
And sluggards unsinew’d lie snoring in bed,
We sons of the chase taste the joys of the morn,
Awak’d at the call of the mellow ton’d horn.44 Horn used by huntsmen to direct hounds, followers, and whips.
Thro’ woodlands and valleys we range for our prey,
Where the hair from her covert starts fearful away;
The high mettl’s courser55 Highly spirited steed. outstrips the fleet wind,
And the landscape, diminished, seems flying behind.
These sports give a zest to the joys of the bowl,
Where mirth and good liquor enliven the soul;
The hall echoes loud to each favorite strain,
And the chase is renew’d in description again.
Let cynical mortal, like sages of yore,
Sit musing, the will of the fates, to explore,
Since life is uncertain, and soon flies away,
Let us die when we will, we’ll be happy to-day.
The mellow ton’d horn, the mellow ton’d horn,
How sweet in the morn,
To follow the hounds,
To follow the hounds and the mellow ton'd horn.
